item.title: What is TTFB and Why You Should Care
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Time To First Byte (TTFB) is one of the most important metrics for website performance. Understanding TTFB can mean the difference between a fast, responsive website and one that feels sluggish to visitors.

What is TTFB?

TTFB stands for Time To First Byte. It measures how long it takes from when a browser requests a page until it receives the first byte of data from the server. Think of it as the initial response time of your website.

What Affects TTFB

Several factors contribute to your TTFB:

  1. Server processing time (PHP execution, database queries)
  2. Network latency between user and server
  3. SSL/TLS handshake overhead
  4. Server configuration and resources

TTFB Benchmarks

What's considered a good TTFB? Here are the typical ranges:

"TTFB is the foundation of page speed. You can optimize everything else, but if your server is slow to respond, users will notice."

How Caching Improves TTFB

  • Skip PHP execution - Cached pages bypass WordPress entirely
  • No database queries - Content is served directly from memory
  • Reduced server load - More resources available for uncached requests
  • Consistent performance - Response times stay fast under load

With full page caching, TTFB can drop from 500ms+ to under 50ms—a 10x improvement that users will immediately feel.
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn what Time To First Byte means for your website and how caching dramatically improves it.

item.title: Scale Your WordPress Site for High Traffic
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Every successful website eventually faces the challenge of scaling. When traffic grows, your infrastructure needs to grow with it. Here's how to prepare your WordPress site for high-traffic scenarios.

The Scaling Challenge

WordPress is powerful and flexible, but out of the box it's not optimized for massive scale. Each page request typically involves:

  • Multiple database queries
  • PHP execution
  • Template rendering
  • Plugin and theme processing

At scale, these operations multiply. A site handling 100 concurrent users has very different requirements than one handling 10,000.

Caching: Your First Line of Defense

Full page caching is the single most effective way to handle traffic spikes. By serving pre-generated HTML pages, you eliminate the need for PHP execution and database queries on every request.

Without Caching

  • ~200-500ms response time
  • High CPU usage
  • Database bottleneck
  • Limited concurrent users

With Caching

  • ~10-50ms response time
  • Minimal CPU usage
  • Database mostly idle
  • Thousands of concurrent users

Beyond Caching: Complete Scaling Strategy

  1. Implement full page caching - Essential first step
  2. Use a CDN - Distribute content globally
  3. Optimize your database - Proper indexing and query optimization
  4. Consider horizontal scaling - Multiple servers behind a load balancer
  5. Monitor everything - You can't optimize what you don't measure

With MilliCache handling your page caching, you've already addressed the biggest performance bottleneck. The rest is optimization and infrastructure planning.
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn how to prepare your WordPress site for high traffic with caching and scaling strategies.

item.title: Understanding Redis for WordPress
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Redis is an in-memory data store that has become essential infrastructure for high-performance WordPress sites. Let's explore what Redis is and why it matters for your website.

What is Redis?

Redis (Remote Dictionary Server) is an open-source, in-memory data structure store. Unlike traditional databases that store data on disk, Redis keeps everything in RAM, making it incredibly fast.

Key Redis Features

  • In-memory storage - Sub-millisecond response times
  • Data persistence - Optional disk backup for durability
  • Rich data types - Strings, lists, sets, hashes, and more
  • Atomic operations - Safe concurrent access
  • Built-in replication - High availability support

Redis vs Other Solutions

WordPress and Redis

In WordPress, Redis is commonly used for:

  1. Object caching - Store database query results
  2. Full page caching - Store complete rendered pages
  3. Session storage - User session data
  4. Transients - Temporary WordPress data

MilliCache uses Redis as its primary storage backend, taking advantage of Redis's speed and reliability to deliver cached pages in milliseconds.

Getting Started with Redis

Most managed WordPress hosts offer Redis as an add-on. For self-hosted sites, Redis installation is straightforward on most Linux distributions. Once installed, MilliCache will automatically detect and use your Redis server.
item.excerpt:encoded: Discover what Redis is and why it's the preferred caching backend for high-performance WordPress sites.

item.title: Why Page Speed Matters for SEO
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Page speed isn't just about user experience—it directly impacts your search engine rankings. Google has made site performance a ranking factor, and slow sites are penalized in search results.

Core Web Vitals

Google's Core Web Vitals are the specific metrics that matter most for SEO:

  • Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) - How fast the main content loads. Target: under 2.5 seconds
  • First Input Delay (FID) - How quickly the page responds to interaction. Target: under 100ms
  • Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS) - Visual stability of the page. Target: under 0.1

How Caching Improves Core Web Vitals

Full page caching dramatically improves all three Core Web Vitals:

LCP Impact

Cached pages load 10-100x faster because they skip PHP execution entirely. Your LCP can drop from seconds to milliseconds.

FID Impact

With the server responding instantly, the browser can focus on rendering and interactivity rather than waiting for data.

Real-World SEO Benefits

Sites that improve their page speed typically see:

  1. Higher search rankings for competitive keywords
  2. Lower bounce rates from organic traffic
  3. Better crawl efficiency from search engines
  4. Improved mobile search performance

"Speed is a ranking factor. Period. If two pages have similar content and relevance, the faster one will rank higher."

Investing in caching is one of the highest-ROI activities for SEO. MilliCache helps you achieve the speed metrics that search engines reward.
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn how page speed affects your SEO rankings and why caching is essential for search visibility.

item.title: Getting Started with Full Page Caching
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Full page caching is the most impactful performance optimization you can make for your WordPress site. This guide will help you understand how it works and what to expect.

How Full Page Caching Works

When a visitor requests a page, WordPress normally:

  1. Receives the HTTP request
  2. Loads WordPress core, plugins, and theme
  3. Queries the database for content
  4. Renders the page using PHP
  5. Sends the HTML response

With full page caching, steps 2-4 are skipped entirely. The complete HTML page is stored and served directly, bypassing WordPress for cached requests.

What Gets Cached

Full page caching works best for:

  • Blog posts and articles
  • Static pages (About, Contact, etc.)
  • Archive pages and category listings
  • Product pages for logged-out users

What Shouldn't Be Cached

Some pages need to remain dynamic:

  • Shopping carts and checkout pages
  • User account dashboards
  • Pages with real-time data
  • Form submission confirmations

Measuring Success

After enabling caching, you should see:

MilliCache makes this process automatic. Once configured, your pages are cached and served at lightning speed with no additional effort required.
item.excerpt:encoded: A beginner's guide to understanding and implementing full page caching for WordPress.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
MilliCache is a high-performance full page caching plugin for WordPress, designed for speed and simplicity.

Fast by Default

MilliCache stores complete HTML pages in Redis, serving them in milliseconds without any PHP execution or database queries. Your visitors get instant page loads, and your server stays cool under pressure.

Simple to Use

No complex configuration required. Install the plugin, connect to Redis, and you're done. MilliCache handles the rest automatically—caching pages, clearing stale content, and optimizing delivery.

Built for WordPress

MilliCache understands WordPress. It knows when to cache, when to clear, and when to bypass. Content updates, new comments, and setting changes automatically trigger appropriate cache updates.

Get in Touch
item.excerpt:encoded: Learn about MilliCache, the high-performance caching plugin for WordPress.

item.title: WordPress Caching Fundamentals
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Everything you need to know about caching in WordPress, from basic concepts to implementation.

About This Book

This comprehensive guide covers all the fundamental concepts of WordPress caching. Whether you're new to caching or looking to deepen your understanding, this book provides a solid foundation.

What You'll Learn

  • Different types of caching in WordPress
  • How browsers, servers, and CDNs cache content
  • The WordPress object cache explained
  • Full page caching strategies
  • Cache invalidation concepts
  • Choosing the right caching solution

Who This Book Is For

This book is perfect for WordPress developers, site administrators, and anyone responsible for website performance. No prior caching experience required.

Book Details

Topics:
item.excerpt:encoded: A comprehensive guide to understanding WordPress caching fundamentals.

item.title: Redis Deep Dive
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Master Redis from the ground up. This technical guide covers everything from basic operations to advanced patterns used in production systems.

Why Redis?

Redis has become the standard for high-performance caching. Its speed, reliability, and rich feature set make it the preferred choice for demanding applications.

Topics Covered

  1. Redis architecture and data structures
  2. Installation and configuration
  3. Performance tuning and optimization
  4. Persistence and durability options
  5. Replication and high availability
  6. Security best practices
  7. Monitoring and troubleshooting

Code Examples

# Basic Redis operations
SET page:/about "cached_html_content"
GET page:/about
EXPIRE page:/about 3600
DEL page:/about

Each chapter includes practical examples and real-world scenarios to help you apply what you learn.

Book Details

Genre:

Topics:
item.excerpt:encoded: A technical deep dive into Redis for web developers and system administrators.

item.title: Scaling WordPress to Millions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Learn the strategies and techniques used by the world's largest WordPress sites. This advanced guide covers everything you need to know about scaling WordPress for massive traffic.

Beyond the Basics

When your site grows beyond what a single server can handle, you need a different approach. This book covers the advanced patterns and architectures that power high-traffic WordPress installations.

Advanced Topics

  • Load balancing and horizontal scaling
  • Database optimization and replication
  • CDN configuration and edge caching
  • Microservices architecture with WordPress
  • Handling traffic spikes and viral content
  • Infrastructure automation and DevOps

Real Numbers
